entry.label: Loose
entry.description: service instance is loosely coupled with a data instance, i.e. no MD_DataIdentification class has to be described

entry.label: Mixed
entry.description: Service instance is mixed coupled with a data instance, i.e. MD_DataIdentification describes the associated data instance and additionally the service instance might work with other external data instances

entry.label: Tight
entry.description: Service instance is tightly coupled with a data instance, i.e. MD_DataIdentification class MUST be described

entry.label: 8.1 Stratigraphy
entry.description: The study of rock layers (strata) and layering (stratification), dealing with the description of all rock bodies form the Earth’s crust— sedimentary, igneous, and metamorphic— and their organization into distinctive, useful, mappable units based on their inherent properties or attributes. Stratigraphic procedures include the description, classification, naming, and correlation of these units for the purpose of establishing their relationship in space and their succession in time.

entry.label: 8.1.1 Magnetostratigraphy
entry.description: Elements of stratigraphy that deal with the magnetic characteristics of rock units.

entry.label: 8.1.2 Cyclostratigraphy
entry.description: Identification, characterization, correlation, and interpretation of cyclic (periodic or quasi-periodic) variations in the stratigraphic record and, in particular, with their application in geochronology by improving the accuracy and resolution of time-stratigraphic frameworks. It uses astronomical cycles of known periodicities to date and interpret the sedimentary record.

entry.label: 8.1.3 Chronostratigraphy
entry.description: Relative time relations and ages of rock bodies.

entry.label: 8.1.4 Sequence stratigraphy
entry.description: Genetically related facies within a framework of chrono- stratigraphically significant surfaces

entry.label: 8.1.5 Lithotratigraphy
entry.description: Description and nomenclature of the rocks of the Earth based on their lithology and their stratigraphic relations.

entry.label: 8.1.6 Biostratigraphy
entry.description: Distribution of fossils in the stratigraphic record and the organization of strata into units on the basis of their contained fossils.

entry.label: 8.1.7 Chemostratigraphy
entry.description: Geochemical signals, such as carbonate cycles and isotope cycles, as recorded in the stratigraphic record.

entry.label: 8.1.8 Event stratigraphy
entry.description: Study of stratigraphic traces of relatively short-lived events (instant to thousands of years) compared to those normally observed on a geological time-scale. Events may be represented by depositional, erosional or geochemical features. (http://quaternary.stratigraphy.org/stratigraphic-guide/event-stratigraphy/)

entry.label: 8.1.9 Geologic time scale
entry.description: Representation of time based on the rock record of Earth, using chronostratigraphy and geochronology. It is used primarily to describe the timing and relationships of events in geologic history. (From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia)

entry.label: 8.2 Paleontology
entry.description: Study of life in the geologic past, based on examination of fossilized remains of once living organisms to clarify their taxonomic classification and interactions with each other and their environments (their paleoecology).

entry.label: 8.2.1 Paleoecology
entry.description: Study of interactions between organisms and/or interactions between organisms and their environments across geologic timescales. As a discipline, paleoecology interacts with, depends on and informs a variety of fields including paleontology, ecology, climatology and biology.

entry.label: 8.2.2 Fossil
entry.description: Description of remnants, impressiosn, or traces of an animal or plant of a past geologic age, preserved in the rock record. The preserved remains or replaced remains (casts) of plants or animals. A fossil type may have one or more described associated organisms. If particle type is materialFossil, an additional type property element may provide a reference to a Paleontologic description of the fossil.

entry.label: 8.2.3 Evolutionary paleontology
entry.description: Information related to reconstruction of the history of life on earth (historical paleontology, phylogeny) and the patterns and causes of evolutionary change and extinction (biological and physical processes and unique historical events).

entry.label: 8.2.4 Biostratigraphy
entry.description: Correlation and assignment of relative age of rock strata using fossil assemblages contained within them. The primary objective of biostratigraphy is correlation, demonstrating that a particular horizon in one geological section represents the same period of time as another horizon at a different section.

entry.label: 8.2.5 Paleoanthropology
entry.description: Study of early development of anatomically modern humans, through the reconstruction of evolutionary kinship lines within the family Hominidae, working from biological evidence (such as petrified skeletal remains, bone fragments, footprints) and cultural evidence (such as stone tools, artifacts, and settlement localities).

entry.label: 8.2.6 Ichnology
entry.description: Study of fossils traces that record biological activity, but are not the preserved remains of the plant or animal itself, including the tracks, borings, trails, burrows, impressions, and others left by ancient organisms. The study of Ichnology is to gain insight into ancient organisms' behavior and ecology.

entry.label: 8.2.7 Invertebrate Paleontology
entry.description: Study of ancient invertebrates by analyzing invertebrate fossils in the geologic record.

entry.label: 8.2.8 Molecular Paleontology
entry.description: Recovery and analysis of DNA, proteins, carbohydrates, or lipids, and their diagenetic products from ancient human, animal, and plant remains.

entry.label: 8.2.9 Geobiology
entry.description: Study of the interactions between the physical Earth and the biosphere. Geobiology focuses on microorganisms, and on the role that life plays in altering the chemical and physical environment of the pedosphere, which exists at the intersection of the lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere and/or cryosphere.

entry.label: 8.2.10 Paleobotany
entry.description: Study of the recovery and identification of plant remains from geological contexts, and their use for the biological reconstruction of past environments, and the evolutionary history of plants, with a bearing upon the evolution of life in general. Paleobotany includes the study of terrestrial plant fossils and prehistoric marine photoautotrophs, such as photosynthetic algae, seaweeds or kelp.

entry.label: 8.2.11 Palynology
entry.description: Study of contemporary and fossil palynomorphs, including pollen, spores, orbicules, dinocysts, acritarchs, chitinozoans and scolecodonts, together with particulate organic matter and kerogen found in sedimentary rocks and sediments.

entry.label: 8.2.12 Taphonomy
entry.description: Study of how organisms decay and become fossilized or preserved in the fossil record.

entry.label: 8.2.13 Micropaleontology
entry.description: Study of microfossils (generally smaller than 1 mm) that require using microscope to observe and to study organism's morphology and characteristic details.

entry.label: 8.2.14 Paleobiogeography
entry.description: Study of the past geographic distribution of organisms based on the fossil record. Incorporates ecology, evolution, and geological processes, and use of the fossil record provides a time component that results in multiple time slices to examine biogeographic pattern.

entry.label: 8.3 Geochronology
entry.description: The science of determining the age of rocks, fossils, and sediments using signatures inherent in the rocks themselves, using radioactive isotopes, paleomagnetism, stable isotope ratios or other physical evidence. By combining multiple geochronological (and biostratigraphic) indicators the precision of the recovered age can be improved.

entry.label: 8.3.1 Radio isotopic dating
entry.description: Geochronolgy based on the rates of radiogenic decay which is proportional to time.

entry.label: 8.3.2 Non-radio isotopic dating
entry.description: Geochronology that does not rely on the measurements of radiogenic decay.

entry.label: 8.4 Sedimentology
entry.description: Study of the physical and chemical properties of sediments and sedimentary rocks and the processes involved in their formation. The interpretation of ancient environmental conditions in sediment source areas and depositional sites is a key objective of such study. Sedimentologists examine the constituents, textures, structures, and fossil content of deposits formed in various geographic environments. (https://www.vedantu.com/geography/sedimentology). Scope includes any material formed by accumulation of solid fragmental material deposited by air, water or ice, or material that accumulated by other natural agents such as chemical precipitation from solution or secretion by organisms.

entry.label: 8.4.1 Sedimentary rock
entry.description: Study of sedimentary rocks, which formed by accumulation and cementation of solid fragmental material deposited by air, water or ice, or as a result of other natural agents, such as precipitation from solution, the accumulation of organic material, or from biogenic processes, including secretion by organisms. (CGI)

entry.label: 8.4.2 Sedimentary physical property
entry.description: The study of physical features of a sedimentary environment includes water depth and the velocity and persistence of currents. (Wikipedia)

entry.label: 8.4.3 Sedimentary geochemistry
entry.description: Sedimentary geochemistry has been in use to understand the conditions of deposition, climatic variations, tectonic setting, provenance, reservoir characteristics, etc. Chemical characteristics of an environment include the salinity (proportion of dissolved salts), acidity or basicity (pH), oxidation potential (Eh). For characterization of depositional units for distinction and correlation based on stratigraphic variation of geochemical traits, usage of the term “chemostratigraphy” has been more frequent since the 1980s. (ScienceDirect)

entry.label: 8.4.4 Sedimentary process
entry.description: Study of how sedimentary rocks are formed, including erosion, weathering, dissolution, lithification, precipitation, etc. (WorldAtlas)

entry.label: 8.5 Magmatic petrology
entry.description: Study of macroscopic and microscopic mineralogical and chemical composition of igneous rocks (or magmatic rocks)—formed through the cooling and solidification of molten material (magma or lava) either within the earth’s crust or at crust the surface of the earth. The modern study of igneous rocks utilizes many techniques, some of them developed in the fields of chemistry, physics, or other earth sciences. Mineralogy, crystallography, and isotopy studies are common methods used in igneous petrology. (from “Igneous rocks” by Jerram D. and Petford N. (2004), Robin Gill (2010) and Wikipedia).

entry.label: 8.5.1 Composition and classification
entry.description: Mineral and geochemical composition of igneous rocks. The classification of igneous rocks refers to classifying igneous rocks according to their mineral and geochemical compositions. The rocks are generally classified into ultramafic, mafic, intermediate, and acidic igneous rocks, and some special and unclassified igneous rocks. (from “Igneous rocks” by Tomkeieff S.T.(1983), R.W.Le Maitre (2002), Best M G (2003) and Wikipedia)

entry.label: 8.5.2 Geochemical properties
entry.description: Study of major, trace element, and isotopic composition of igneous rocks. The chemistry of igneous systems provides clues to many important whole-earth evolution processes, including the origins of igneous, processes and timing of planetary differentiation, the production and destruction of the lithosphere, and the relationships between magmatic styles, composition, crust growth, mantle-crust convection, and plate-tectonic environment.

entry.label: 8.5.3 Physical properties
entry.description: Study of the observable, measurable, and describable physical properties of igneous rocks and magma processes, including the occurrence in the field, texture, (ductile and brittle) structure of igneous rocks, as well as the physical properties of magma, such as temperature, pressure, and rheology etc. (from “Igneous rocks” by Jerram D. and Petford N. (2004) and Wikipedia)

entry.label: 8.5.4 Magmatism and origin
entry.description: Study of the origin and emplacement of magma within or at the surface of the outer layers of a terrestrial planet to form igneous rocks. Includes the production, intrusion, and extrusion of magma or lava. Volcanism is the surface expression of magmatism. The origin of igneous rocks is to study the source of magma, magma generation, magmatism, and other properties related to igneous formation. (from “Igneous rocks” by Robin Gill (2010) and Wikipedia)

entry.label: 8.6 Metamorphic petrology
entry.description: Study of the transformation of existing rock to new types of rock through solid-state mineralogical, chemical and/or structural changes.

entry.label: 8.6.1 Metamorphic fabrics
entry.description: Study of the relative orientation of parts of a metamorphic rock mass, including metamorphic textures and structures. Metamorphic textures develop in the solid state as mineral grains interact with their neighbors during deformation, recrystallization, and/or growth. Structure is the arrangement of the parts of a rock mass irrespective of scale, including spatial relationships between the parts, their relative size and shape and the internal features of the parts.

entry.label: 8.6.2 Dynamic metamorphism
entry.description: Study of metamorphism of local extent, associated with fault zones or shear zones.

entry.label: 8.6.3 Impact metamorphism
entry.description: Study of metamorphism caused by the passage of a shock wave due to the impact of a planetary body (projectile or impactor) on a planetary surface (target). It includes melting and vaporization of the target rock(s).

entry.label: 8.6.4 Contact metamorphism
entry.description: Study of metamorphism that affects the rocks adjacent to magma bodies emplaced in a variety of environments from volcanic to upper mantle depths, in both continental and oceanic settings.

entry.label: 8.6.5 Metasomatism
entry.description: Study of metamorphic processes through which the chemical composition of a rock body is altered, involving the introduction and/or removal of chemical components as a result of the interaction of the rock with aqueous or other fluids. During metasomatism the rock remains in a solid state.

entry.label: 8.6.6 Regional metamorphism
entry.description: Study of metamorphism that occurs over a wide extent, affecting a large rock volume, associated with large-scale tectonic processes, such as ocean-floor spreading, crustal thickening related to plate collision, deep basin subsidence, etc.

entry.label: 8.6.7 Ocean-floor metamorphism
entry.description: Study of metamorphism related to the steep geothermal gradients occurring near spreading centers in oceanic environments.

entry.label: 8.6.8 Burial metamorphism
entry.description: Study of metamorphism resulting from deep burial under a sedimentary or volcanic accumulation, typically not associated with deformation or magmatism.

entry.label: 8.6.9 Migmatite
entry.description: Study of silicate metamorphic rock, pervasively heterogeneous on a meso- to megascopic scale, typically consisting of darker and lighter parts. The darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks whereas the lighter parts are of igneous-looking appearance.

entry.label: 8.6.10 Metamorphic history
entry.description: Study of the temporal sequence of metamorphic facies, metamorphic series, metamorphic zones, and P-T-t paths in a rock or a geological unit. A metamorphic facies is a set of metamorphic mineral assemblages, repeatedly associated in time and space and showing a regular relationship between mineral composition and bulk chemical composition. A series of metamorphic facies developed under a particular range of P/T. A succession of metamorphic zones characterized by distinctive index minerals.

entry.label: 8.7 Structure geology
entry.description: Study of the three-dimensional distribution of rock units with respect to their deformational histories. The primary goal of structural geology is to use measurements of present-day rock geometries to uncover information about the history of deformation (strain) in rocks, and ultimately, to understand the stress field that resulted in the observed strain and geometries.

entry.label: 8.7.1 Historical structure
entry.description: Study of deformational histories of rock units that occured before Quaternary time.

entry.label: 8.7.2 Active and Neo structure
entry.description: Study of recent tectonic deformation and tectonic geomorphic evolution on the Earth. Neo-structure concerns geological processes at time scales from Ma to ka, and emphasizes on the relationship between the past and present tectonic deformation. Active tectonics is focused on geological–geomorphological processes since 100 to 150ka, present, and future tectonic deformation. Active structure is typically used to describe those movement that have occurred over the timespan of human history and deals with the societal implications of ongoing deformation, such as seismic-hazard assessment, future sea-level rise, i.e. crustal movements that can be expected to recur within a future interval of concern to society.

entry.label: 8.8 Tectonics
entry.description: Study of the processes that control the structure and properties of the Earth's crust and its evolution through time.

entry.label: 8.8.1 Plate tectonics
entry.description: Study of the motion and interaction between relatively rigid plates that comprise the Earth's crust. These motions account for most observable tectonic activity in the Earth, as well as the tectonic history recorded in the ocean basins. The theory of plate tectonics holds that the Earth's lithosphere is divided into a set of major and minor relatively rigid plates that are in motion with respect to one another and that the motion of each plate is, to a first approximation, a rigid-body motion.

entry.label: 8.8.2 Deep Earth tectonics
entry.description: Study of Earth's interior layers and related features, including mantle, core, subducting slab, plume, LLSVPs, discontinuities etc., beneath the depth of the Moho surface.

entry.label: 8.8.3 Thermochronology
entry.description: Study of the thermal evolution of a region of a planet. Thermochronology uses radiometric dating along with the concept of closure temperature that represents the temperature of the mineral being studies at the time given by the date recorded to understand the thermal history of a specific rock, mineral, or geologic unit. Thermochronology is closely associated with geochronology.

entry.label: 8.8.4 Geodynamics
entry.description: Study of dynamic processes in the Earth, applying physics, chemistry, geology, and mathematics to the understanding of how mantle convections lead to plate tectonics and geologic phenomena such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting etc. Methods of Geodynamics are also applied to exploration other planets.

entry.label: 8.9 Geologic mapping
entry.description: Study or documentation of the interpretive, geoscientific processes to produce depictions of the distribution of rocks and geologic structures in the Earth. Scope includes a range of map products for many different uses, including assessing ground-water quality and contamination risks; predicting earthquake, volcano, and landslide hazards; characterizing energy and mineral resources and their extraction costs; waste repository siting; land management and land-use planning; and general education. The products include geological, tectonic, seismological, geophysical and geochemical maps at different scales.

entry.label: 8.9.1 Geological survey
entry.description: Study or documentation of the process of collecting geological data by a variety of methods such as field profiling, drilling, remote sensing and sampling etc.

entry.label: 8.9.2 Geological compilation
entry.description: Study or documentation of geoscience map compilation. A geological map may be compiled from other maps, usually of larger scale, or may be produced from original geoscientific surveys and photogrammetric compilations.

entry.label: 8.9.3 Digital geological mapping
entry.description: Study or documentation of the process of using computer software to create a digital geological map or to construct database of geological maps.

entry.label: 8.10 Hydrogeology
entry.description: Study of the distribution and movement of groundwater in the soil and rocks of the Earth's crust, commonly in aquifers. Geology of ground water and hydrology, also including ground water dynamic, mining hydrogeology, regional hydrogeology, etc.

entry.label: 8.10.1 Storage of groundwater
entry.description: Study of the hydrological properties of rock and soil as they relate to water as a constituent of the rock body.

entry.label: 8.10.2 Groundwater flow
entry.description: Study of he movement of water through soil or rock bodies in the subsurface.

entry.label: 8.10.3 Groundwater quality
entry.description: Study of the physical, chemical and biological properties of groundwater related to its utilization for human activities.

entry.label: 8.10.4 Geological processes of groundwater
entry.description: Study of the relationship between geologic processes and the occurrence and movement of groundwater.

entry.label: 8.10.5 Groundwater dependent ecosystems
entry.description: Study of ecosystems that depend on groundwater permanently or intermittently to meet all or some of their water requirements so as to maintain their communities of plants and animals, ecological processes and ecosystem services.

entry.label: 8.11 Engineering geology(geotechnology)
entry.description: Investigation, study and solution of the engineering and environmental problems that arise as the result of the interaction between geology and the activities of humans, and the prediction and development of measures for prevention or remediation of geological hazards.

entry.label: 8.11.1 Regional engineering geology
entry.description: Study of the geologic stability of a particular region that might be affected by crustal movements, volcanic activity or fault activity, especially focused on those activities which might trigger earthquakes and consequent regional mass wasting processes such as rock falls, landslides, debris flow, liquefaction, plastic flows of clay, and uneven surface subsidence.

entry.label: 8.11.2 Soil mass engineering geology
entry.description: Study of engineering properties of soil to solve geological problems related to engineering activities, and propose technical measures for improvement and hazard prevention in the planning, design, construction, use and development of engineering activities.

entry.label: 8.11.3 Rock mass engineering geology
entry.description: Study of the laws of formation and evolution of rock masses and their engineering behavior through the theories and methods of geomechanics.

entry.label: 8.11.4 Applied engineering geology
entry.description: Collection and evaluation of data useful for the design and engineering of structures. The subject comprises the modes of application of engineering geology, case histories, evaluation of investigations, design and realization of structures as well as their observation during and after construction.

entry.label: 8.11.5 Geological hazards
entry.description: Study and assessment of natural geologic processes or man-made geologic conditions that represent a present-day or future hazard to man's life, health, or property. Six typical geological hazards, i.e., landslides, debris flows, rockfalls, avalanches, earthquakes, and volcanoes.

entry.label: 8.11.6 Intelligent engineering geology
entry.description: Studies that combine innovative concepts with the new generation of information technology to intelligently collect geologic information useful for engineering, mine existing engineering geology knowledge, reveal spatial-temporal characteristics and the evolution of engineering geological bodies, and predict their future development trends.

entry.label: 8.12 Environmental geology
entry.description: study of the practical application of the principles of geology to solving environmental problems created by man. It is a multidisciplinary field that is closely related to engineering geology and, to a lesser extent, to environmental geography (Wikipedia)

entry.label: 8.13 Petroleum geology
entry.description: Study of the origin, occurrence, movement, accumulation, and exploration of hydrocarbon fuels. It refers to the specific set of geological disciplines that are applied to the search for hydrocarbons (oil exploration).

entry.label: 8.13.1 Oil and gas resources assessment
entry.description: Evaluation of oil and gas resources to estimate the subsurface oil and gas endowment in a specific geological entity.

entry.label: 8.13.2 Geological elements
entry.description: Study of the geological elements related to origin, occurrence, movement, and accumulation of oil or gas resources, including source rocks, reservoirs, seals and traps.

entry.label: 8.13.3 Petroleum accumulation
entry.description: Study of the geological process of oil and gas entrapment in rock bodies through migration in the carrier beds and finally filling into traps following the generation of oil and gas.

entry.label: 8.14 Mathematical geoscience
entry.description: Study of the application of mathematical methods to solve problems in geosciences.

entry.label: 8.14.1 Data visualization‎
entry.description: Study and documentation of techniques for graphical representation of geoscience information and data.

entry.label: 8.14.2 Analysis
entry.description: Description of the analysis of geologic problems amenable to mathematical modeling. Analysis is the process of breaking a complex topic or substance into smaller parts in order to gain a better understanding of it.

entry.label: 8.14.3 Modelling
entry.description: Study, documentation and development of conceptualizations that can be used to explain observed data, and implementation of these conceptualizations in software to compare predicted behavior to the actual observed data, or to predict the outcome of an event.

entry.label: 8.14.4 Computation
entry.description: Study and documentation of algorithms and implementation of algorithms in computer systems to build models or solve problems. Computation is any type of calculation that includes both arithmetical and non-arithmetical steps and follows a well-defined algorithm.

entry.label: 8.15 Marine geology
entry.description: Study of the history and structure of the ocean floor from shorelines to the continental shelf and deep sea. It involves geophysical, geochemical, sedimentological and paleontological investigations of the ocean floor and coastal zone.

entry.label: 8.15.1 Submarine geomorphology
entry.description: Study of the morphology and evolution of seafloor landforms, and the processes responsible for their formation, in particular erosion and depositional processes, sediment movement and deformation, volcanic activity, fluid migration, and anthropogenic impacts.

entry.label: 8.15.2 Marine sedimentology
entry.description: Description, classification, modeling, and interpretation of marine sediments so as to determine the physical, chemical, and biological processes by which they formed.

entry.label: 8.15.3 Marine sediment dynamics
entry.description: Study of the motion of sediment particles during their formation, transport, and settling processes (Zhang, 2014).

entry.label: 8.15.4 Paleoceanography and paleoclimatology
entry.description: Study of the circulation, chemistry, biology, geology and patterns of sedimentation and biological productivity of the oceans and climates as they were in the past, from a few hundred years to billions of years ago (Thomas, 2009).

entry.label: 8.15.5 Marine geochronology
entry.description: Determination of ages and time intervals for geologic materials, including marine sediments, and processes on geologic, archeologic, and historic time scales. It is the science of investigating the chronology of the earth constituents as induced from geologic data, based on absolute and relative dating methods.

entry.label: 8.15.6 Marine petrology
entry.description: Study of the mineralogy, textures, and chemical composition of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks from the ocean floor, since their composition reflects the conditions at which they were formed and the time they needed to develop.

entry.label: 8.15.7 Marine geochemistry
entry.description: Study of the chemistry of geological materials such as rocks, sediments and water from the ocean or ocean floor.

entry.label: 8.15.8 Seafloor tectonics and geodynamics
entry.description: Study of the genesis, aging, motion, and destruction of oceanic plates (Koppers and Coggon, 2020) and their interactions with the earth’s interior.

entry.label: 8.15.9 Marine geohazards
entry.description: Study of geological conditions at the sea floor or within sub-bottom sediments that could result in dangerous or catastrophic events with attendant risks to life and/or infrastructure. The major marine geohazards are coastal erosion, seawater intrusion, earthquakes, submarine landslides, subsidence, tsunamis, natural gas hydrate dissociation, seabed sand waves, shallow gas, overpressure strata, gas chimneys, mud volcanoes and mud diapirism

entry.label: 8.15.10 Coastal morphodynamics
entry.description: Study of the changes in the morphology of the coastal zone, including the topography of the sea bed and the shoreline planform, in connection with waves, currents, tides and sea level rise.

entry.label: 8.15.11 Marine paleontology and micropaleontology
entry.description: Study of ancient fossils and microfossils in the sediments in order to reconstruct past conditions of oceans and environments.

entry.label: 8.15.12 Seafloor habitat
entry.description: Study of physical structure, dimensions, and biological characteristics of specific species or groups of species occupying the seafloor (Diaz et al. 2004).

entry.label: 8.15.13 Subseafloor biosphere
entry.description: Study of the subseafloor ecosystem and environments (e.g., hydrothermal systems and cold seeps) that sustain them.

entry.label: 8.16 Mineralogy
entry.description: Study of natural minerals that formed on Earth and or were delivered from other planets.

entry.label: 8.16.1 Mineral properties and applications
entry.description: Study of the properties of minerals, for understanding geological phenomena and synthesizing new materials.

entry.label: 8.16.2 Crystallography
entry.description: Study of the external form and the crystal structure of crystalline solids and the principles that govern their growth, shape, and internal atomic arrangement.

entry.label: 8.16.3 Mineral genesis and occurrence
entry.description: Study of minerals characteristics, species and assemblages as they relate to the physical and chemical conditions of conditions and genetic processes.

entry.label: 8.16.4 Mineral classification and description
entry.description: Study of schemes for mineral classifications that are determined in the light of chemical composition and internal structure.

entry.label: 8.16.5 Chemical composition and crystal structure
entry.description: Study of the identity and number of the chemical elements that make up any particular mineral the ordered arrangement of atoms, ions or molecules in a crystalline material.

entry.label: 8.17 Gravimetric and gravity exploration
entry.description: Study and measurement of the strength of a gravitational field, the properties of matter responsible for its creation, and applications of this data for understanding the solid earth and for geological exploration. Gravity exploration is one of the common and primary geophysical exploration methods. It is based on the density difference between the target object and its surroundings.

entry.label: 8.18 Geomagnetism and magnetic exploration
entry.description: Study and measurement of the Earth’s total magnetic field or components of the field in various directions to solve problems of geosciences and for exploration. Applications are to investigate subsurface geology on the basis of anomalies in the Earth’s magnetic field resulting from the magnetic properties of the underlying rocks.

entry.label: 8.19 Geoelectricity and electrical exploration
entry.description: Study and measurement of the electrical parameters of underground geological structures, media and bodies (rocks, sediments, water, voids, etc.) both passive or active methods, to solve geoscience problems and for exploration. Electrical exploration is an applied discipline that observes and studies electric and electromagnetic fields established naturally or artificially underground, and solves various geological problems related to the difference in the electrical properties of rock bodies.

entry.label: 8.20 Seismology and seismic exploration
entry.description: Study of the propagation of elastic waves through the Earth or through other planet-like bodies, including studies for petroleum and other resources exploration, and study of earthquake and relevant environmental effects such as tsunamis as well as diverse seismic sources such as volcanic, tectonic, glacial, fluvial, oceanic, atmospheric, and artificial processes such as explosions.

entry.label: 8.21 Nuclear geophysics and radioactive exploration
entry.description: Study and measurement of the radioactive characteristics of subsurface rocks bodies, rocks or minerals, with applcations in mineral exploration and to solve geological problems.

entry.label: 8.22 Drill and geophysical logging
entry.description: Documentation and collection of data for physical and petrophysical properties of subsurface materials acquired using instruments lowered into boreholes. Geophysical logging is based on physics (electric, nuclear, magnetic, etc.), mathematics and geology as the theoretical basis.

entry.label: 8.22.1 Instruments for drilling and well logging
entry.description: Description of instruments and technology used for drilling boreholes, colleting rock and sediment samples, and collecting subsurface data in boreholes.

entry.label: 8.22.2 Coring and core analysis
entry.description: Description of instruments and technology used to acquire continuous subsurface samples along a borehole (core), and techniques for measuring properties of the samples at laboratory

entry.label: 8.22.3 Logging data analysis
entry.description: Study of techniques for analyzing data collected by borehole logging instruments, and relating the data to physical properties and geologic events used for correlation.

entry.label: 8.23 Paleomagnetism
entry.description: Study of the record of the Earth's magnetic field in rocks, sediment, or archeological materials to reveal the past behavior of Earth’s magnetic field and the past location of tectonic plates.

entry.label: 8.24 Rock physics
entry.description: Stud of the the behavior and physicochemical properties of rocks in different environments such as surface and underground, including the characteristics of fluid reservoir rocks, as well as their interactions with oil, gas and water. Mainly concerned with the physical properties of pore geology, the interaction between different fluids and rock pore surfaces. It is the theoretical basis of logging, geophysical exploration and reservoir engineering.

entry.label: 8.25 Integrated geophysics
entry.description: Study of the simultaneous application of multiple geophysical methods, including gravity, electrical, magnetic, seismic and other methods in ocean, energy, environmental and other geophysical exploration problems. The combination of multiple geophysical methods can effectively reduce the multi-solution problem in the interpretation of a single geophysical exploration method and improve the reliability of geophysical exploration interpretation.

entry.label: 8.26 Geochemistry
entry.description: Studies that use the tools and principles of chemistry to solve geoscience problems; includes isotope geochemistry, biogeochemistry, organic geochemistry, regional, environmental and exploration geochemistry, rock geochemical exploration, soil geochemical exploration, stream sediment geochemical exploration, atmospheric geochemical exploration, biogeochemical exploration, water geochemical exploration, geo-gas survey, chemical analysis, geochemical mapping, geothermal manifestation, radiometric dating, etc.

entry.label: 8.26.1 Surficial geochemistry
entry.description: Study of the chemical principles and processes active on the Earth surface

entry.label: 8.27 Remote sensing
entry.description: Descriptions acquisition and analysis of information about an object or phenomenon without making physical contact with the object, especially to acquiring information about the Earth from aircraft or satellites, for the study of hydrology, ecology, meteorology, oceanography, glaciology, geology, etc.

entry.label: 8.27.1 Remote sensing infrastructure
entry.description: Study and description of the techniques, hardware, and software to collect and analyze remote sensing data. It is especially associated with those devices and data analysis and process methods of the remote sensing system, including the sensors, sensing platforms, electromagnetic spectrum characteristics, and remote sensing data algorithms.

entry.label: 8.27.2 Applied remote sensing
entry.description: Study of techniques to obtain target information by using remote sensing technology or to obtain target attributes by analyzing remote sensing data.

entry.label: 8.27.3 Photogrammetry
entry.description: Techniques to obtain the shape, size, position, characteristics, and relationships of the subject from remote sensing images. Mostly related to production of topographic maps, establishing topographic databases, provide spatial basic data for various geographic information systems, land information systems, and various projects, and serve non-topographic fields.

entry.label: 8.28 Geomorphology
entry.description: Study of the origin and evolution of physiography, topographic and bathymetric features created by physical, chemical or biological processes operating at or near the Earth's surface.

entry.label: 8.28.1 Special geomorphology
entry.description: Study of the landforms and their geomorphic evolution formed by some geological agents (such as fluvial landforms, aeolian landform, glacial landform, karst landform, coastal landform, etc.) as its independent research object.

entry.label: 8.28.2 Dynamical geomorphology
entry.description: Study of the mechanisms of landform evolution focused on geomorphic processes. It can be divided into endodynamic geomorphology and exokinetic geomorphology. It applies the principles and methods of basic sciences such as mathematics, physics and chemistry, focusing on the modern process of landform formation and the relationship between landform and various action variables.

entry.label: 8.28.3 Regional geomorphology
entry.description: Study of the geomorphology of an area, with analysis of topographic characteristics, genetic dynamics, geomorphic evolution, geographical distribution and composition characteristics. Includes studies at different spatial scales, such as global geomorphology, intercontinental geomorphology, plate geomorphology, national geomorphology, and local regional geomorphology etc.

entry.label: 8.28.4 Applied geomorphology
entry.description: Study of the use of principles and methods of geomorphology to solve practical problems. It links the study of geomorphology closely to the transformation of nature and human decision-making processes. It relates to environmental studies, resource surveys, disaster prevention, soil and water conservation, etc. Applied geomorphology includes multiple sub-fields, for example, agricultural geomorphology, engineering geomorphology and mining geomorphology.

entry.label: 8.28.5 Experimental geomorphology
entry.description: The study of geomorphic process through indoor scale modelling or observation of a selected geomorphic feature under controlled conditions to reveal relationships between the development of landforms and different factors.

entry.label: 8.28.6 Geomorphological mapping
entry.description: Description of the process of visualizing the scale, spatial distribution, classification or regionalization of various geomorphological objects and phenomena on a map. It is an important method and tool for geomorphological investigation and research, as well as a powerful illustration and supplement to the written description of geomorphological phenomena. The results of geomorphological mapping include geomorphological classification maps, geomorphological regionalization maps, etc.

entry.label: 8.28.7 Climatic geomorphology
entry.description: Study of the processes of landform formation and their evolution under different climatic conditions.

entry.label: 8.28.8 Quantitative geomorphology
entry.description: Study of land surface morphology, its formation and development through the analysis of quantitative data using mathematical methods. It includes the acquisition of quantitative data, the quantification of non-quantitative information, the processing and analysis of data, the creation of models and the simulation of geomorphological processes. Includes digital geomorphology, which is a branch of geomorphology that studies surface morphology, landform types, spatial distribution, geomorphic formation and evolution process through comprehensive analysis of remote sensing images, digital terrain model (DTM) and other relevant geomorphic data in a geographic information system environment.

entry.label: 8.28.9 Fractal geomorphology
entry.description: Study of the use of fractal methods and principles to study the surface morphology and its occurrence, development and distribution.

entry.label: 8.28.10 Historical geomorphology
entry.description: Study of the temporal sequence of development of geomorphic features.

entry.label: 8.29 Paleoclimatology
entry.description: Study of reconstruction of ancient climate to understand natural variation and the evolution of the current climate, for which direct measurements were not taken. It utilizes a variety of proxy methods from Earth and life sciences to obtain data previously preserved within rocks, sediments, boreholes, ice sheets, tree rings, corals, shells, and microfossils. Combined with techniques to date the proxies, the paleoclimate records are used to determine the past states of Earth's atmosphere.

entry.label: 8.30 Paleogeography
entry.description: Study of historical geography, generally physical landscapes in the geologic past.

entry.label: 8.30.1 Lithofacies paleogeography
entry.description: Study of the use of lithofacies analysis to reconstruct sedimentary environments and landforms during geological history and to study the distribution and evolution of sedimentary facies, with the task of providing basic theory and applied methods for resource prediction.

entry.label: 8.30.2 Tectono-paleogeography
entry.description: Study of the relationship between geography and plate tectonic development of the Earth , including the location of active plate boundaries and the changing extent of both oceanic and continental plates.

entry.label: 8.30.3 Climate paleogeography
entry.description: Study of the relationship between geography and climate in the geologic past, by adding climatic information to traditional paleogeography maps by using deep time climate classifications.

entry.label: 8.30.4 Paleobiogeography
entry.description: Study of the geographical distribution of faunas and floras in the past.

entry.label: 8.31 Earth resource
entry.description: Study of the occurrence of renewable resources and non-renewable resources that are found in the Earth. Non-renewable resources are the naturally resources that cannot be readily replaced by natural means such as oil and gas, minerals and metal ores, ground water, etc.

entry.label: 8.31.1 Mineral resource
entry.description: Mineral resources of the earth, including mineral geology, mineral exploration, mineral exploitation, etc.

entry.label: 8.31.2 Groundwater
entry.description: Study of groundwater resources of the Earth in aquifers, including groundwater exploration, groundwater production, etc.

entry.label: 8.31.3 Oil and gas
entry.description: Study of oil and gas resources in the Earth, including exploration, exploitation, production, distribution of oil and gas fields, etc.

entry.label: 8.31.4 Shale gas and oil shale
entry.description: Study of the geology, exploration, production of hydrocarbons from of oil shale or shale gas.

entry.label: 8.31.5 Coal and coalbed methane
entry.description: Study of coal geology and coalbed methane geology, coal and coalbed methane exploration, coal and coalbed methane production and products, etc.

entry.label: 8.31.6 Gas hydrate
entry.description: Study of gas hydrate, gas hydrate geology, gas hydrate exploration, gas hydrate exploitation, etc.

entry.label: 8.31.7 Organic material
entry.description: Study of Earth material composed of organic compounds derived from the remains of dead organisms and their waste products in the environment. (CGI)

entry.label: 8.32 Geothermics
entry.description: Study of heat from within the Earth as a natural resource. It includes geothermal geology, geothermal exploration, geothermal exploitation, geothermal tourism, etc.

entry.label: 8.32.1 Theoretical geothermics
entry.description: Study of fundamental topics related to heat in the Earth such as the thermal structure of crust and mantle, the deep thermal state and the formation mechanism and control factors of the thermal evolution of lithosphere structure.

entry.label: 8.32.2 Applied geothermics
entry.description: Studies that investigate geothermal resource types, origin and distribution, geothermal resource exploration, geothermal resource evaluation, geothermal resource development and utilization, and geothermal disaster.

entry.label: 8.32.3 Geothermal energy
entry.description: Study of heat energy that comes from the subsurface of the earth which contained in the rocks and fluids beneath the crust and originates from the formation of the planet or geological movements and radioactive decay of mass materials.

entry.label: 8.32.4 Dry hot rock
entry.description: Study of underground dry hot rock exploration and utility, etc.

entry.label: 8.33 Geo-exploration
entry.description: Desriptions of activities and processes of searching for or discovery of Earth resources. It includes mineral exploration activities such as reconnaissance, assessment and surface and subsurface exploration, ore geology, mining pilot, mining regulation and law, and relevant administration.

entry.label: 8.34 Mining
entry.description: Descriptions of activities and processes for extraction of valuable minerals or other geological materials form the earth.

entry.label: 8.35 Economical geology
entry.description: Study of fuels, metals, and other materials from the Earth that are of interest to industry or the economy in general. It is concerned with the distribution of resources, the costs and benefits of their recovery, and the value and availability of existing materials. (Wikipedia)

entry.label: 8.35.1 Characteristics of ore deposits
entry.description: Study and description of systematic information describing the attributes of the mineral deposits.

entry.label: 8.35.2 Deposit type
entry.description: Classifications of recognized mineral deposits that are defined by physical and genetic factors that can be consistently differentiated from those of other classes or deposit types. (Bureau of Mines. Dictionary of mining, mineral, and related terms[M]. American Geological Institute, 1997)

entry.label: 8.35.3 Ore genesis
entry.description: Study of the origin of economically producable concentrations of a mineral commodity.

entry.label: 8.35.4 Metallogeny
entry.description: Study of the genesis and regional-to-global distribution of metallic mineral deposits, with emphasis on their relationship in space and time to regional petrologic and tectonic features of the Earth's crust. (Gilbert J M, Park Jr C F. The geology of ore deposits[M]. Waveland Press, 2007)

entry.label: 8.36 Geological literature
entry.description: Documentation of literature of or about geology

entry.label: 8.36.1 Dinosaur
entry.description: Study and presentation of dinosaurs for geoscience and the public.

entry.label: 8.36.2 Geopark
entry.description: Study and management of the UNESCO Geopark that are single, unified geographical areas where sites and landscapes of international geological significance are managed with a holistic concept of protection, education and sustainable development.

entry.label: 8.36.3 Geo-education
entry.description: Resources related to in-school and out-of-school learning. In school, geo-education takes place across many subjects in the traditional curriculum. Outside of school, geo-education takes place through guided experience in both the human and natural worlds.

entry.label: 8.36.4 Geological publications
entry.description: Publications of geology, such as books, periodicals, magazines, etc.

entry.label: 8.36.5 Geological archives
entry.description: Geological reports and written materials that mostly are not published

entry.label: 8.37 Planetary geology
entry.description: Study of the geology of the celestial bodies such as the planets and their moons, asteroids, comets, and meteorites. Alternatively known as astrogeology or exogeology

entry.label: 8.38 Biogeology
entry.description: Study of the interactions between the Earth's biosphere and the lithosphere.

entry.label: 8.39 Volcanology
entry.description: Study of volcanoes, lava, magma and related geological, geophysical and geochemical phenomena (volcanism). (Wikipedia)

entry.label: 8.40 Forensic geology
entry.description: Resources about any aspect of geologic science that is subject to public debate in a court of law. Forensic geology applies the defining principles of the geologic sciences to the identification/evaluation of geologic materials that may be related to forensic problems.(John W. Lindemann: ENVIRONMENTAL AND ENGINEERING GEOLOGY - Vol. III)

entry.label: 8.41 Other geoscientific topics
entry.description: Resources related to geoscience that cannot be defined by the above categories.

entry.label: Data science
entry.description: Study that uses scientific methods, processes, algorithms and systems to extract or extrapolate knowledge and insights from noisy, structured and unstructured data, and apply knowledge from data across a broad range of application domains. NOTE data science is related to data mining, machine learning and big data.

entry.label: Missing value
entry.description: Sentinel value to flag that no topic category was provided; need this because ISO19115-3 does not require a topic category.

entry.label: 1.1 Data Access Service
entry.description: Service provide filtering and subsetting functions on one or more datasets, based on URL parameters. Operates on a data store provided by the service backend. Includes services for graph queries (e.g. GQL, Cypher) against a graph database and SPARQL queries against an RDF triple store

entry.label: 1.2 Data workflow service
entry.description: the service provided for geoscience data acquisition/collection, transfer, integration, storage, modelling, analysis and visualization, etc.

entry.label: 1.3 Data processing service
entry.description: services provided on geoscience data processing, including disciplinary data processing tools software service (APP), data processing modules (API), data processing web Apps.

entry.label: 1.4 Map service
entry.description: services to provide a client view, access, or obtain to a geoscientific map product, the graphic data, a vector data map or image map in the format of WMS, WFS, png/jpeg/tiff, etc., for example.

entry.label: 1.5 Other data service
entry.description: data service(s) provided not defined above.

entry.label: 2.1 Geoscience knowledge catalogue service
entry.description: provides services to return the DDE geoscience knowledge directory of specific disciplines/sub disciplines, or keywords.

entry.label: 2.2 Geoscience knowledge content service
entry.description: provides services to return the DDE geoscience knowledge content (knowledge tuples) of specific disciplines/sub disciplines, or keywords.

entry.label: 2.3Knowledge reasoning service
entry.description: provide services to return the related knowledge content (knowledge tuples) obtained by reasoning for the specific keywords

entry.label: 2.4 Deep shovel
entry.description: provides services of searching and finding information and/or knowledge form published papers.

entry.label: 2.5 DDE scholar
entry.description: provides scholar portrait service (literatures and relationships) thru data mining from published journal papers.

entry.label: 2.6 Other knowledge service
entry.description: Other services provided by DDE geoscience knowledge not defined above.

entry.label: 3.1 Catalogue service
entry.description: provides discovery and management services on DDE platform of metadata about instances. The metadata may be for dataset instances, e.g. dataset catalogue, or may contain service metadata, e.g. service catalogue.

entry.label: 3.2 Registry service
entry.description: provides access to DDE platform. Example registries are information community registries, type dictionaries, service registries and schema registries.

entry.label: 3.3 Model Service
entry.description: provides discovery and management services on DDE platform of metadata about models.

entry.label: 3.4 Cloud computing resource service
entry.description: provides web-based computing facilities discovery and management services on DDE platform and DDE Cloud.

entry.label: 3.5Annotation Service
entry.description: provides discovery and management services on DDE platform of metadata about annotations used on the platform.

entry.label: 3.6 API Service
entry.description: provides discovery services on DDE platform of metadata about API information provided by the DDE platform.

entry.label: 3.7 Earth Explorer
entry.description: provides a search engine service to search and visualize information, data and knowledge form DDE platform.

entry.label: 3.8 Data evaluation service
entry.description: service for DDE accessible data evaluation based on six aspects/metrics of authority, quality, volume, openness, service capability and user scale metrics.

entry.label: 3.9 DDE identifier service
entry.description: automatically generation of a DDE data code [resourceIdentifier?] to the data resource registered to be DDE resource

entry.label: 3.10 Other platform service
entry.description: Other services provided by the DDE platform not defined above.

entry.label: 4.1 Mineral resource assessment service
entry.description: service for the regional assessment of specific minerals resources, porphyry copper for example.

entry.label: 4.9 Geologic mapping service (Global layer)
entry.description: services for view, access, and obtain geological map products, as well as complete online mapping and publishing, including relevant symbol libraries, etc.

entry.label: 4.3 Geological timeline service
entry.description: service for accurate geological timing.

entry.label: 4.4 Digital geological occurrence service
entry.description: provides service of visualization of geological observation spots and rock occurrence, etc.

entry.label: 4.5 Dinosaur service
entry.description: provides service of visualized living scenes of a group of specific dinosaurs in geological history.

entry.label: 4.6 Global naming service
entry.description: services for name(s) globally with geographic position.

entry.label: 4.7 Geomorphologic mapping service
entry.description: service for geomorphologic mapping online with relevant data resources.

entry.label: 4.8 Geoscience standards service
entry.description: service for DDE geoscience standards access and download.

entry.label: 4.9 Other thematic service
entry.description: thematic service(s) provided not defined above.

entry.label: Vocabulary service
entry.description: Service implements vocabulary services based on SKOS properties. This category is for generic service provided from source other than DDE platform. Resolve concept URI to preferred label, definitions, related terms; test if a label is present in a vocabulary, return URI for label, etc.

entry.label: Registry service
entry.description: Service provides interface to interact with a non-DDE resource registry; provides capabilities e.g. to resolve URIs to return descriptions of a registered resource, return resource descriptions based on search criteria including labels, free text, or other properties included in registered resource descriptions.

entry.label: Discovery service
entry.description: Service supports searching a non-DDE metadata catalog to locate resources of interest and return metadata records describing those resources.

entry.label: View service
entry.description: Service provides visualizations of geospatial or tabular data. Works with geospatial data not integrated in DDE platform, in which case service type would be 1.4 DataService/MapService

entry.label: Other service
entry.description: Service that does not fit in any other category. . For other values not included in this codelist, use prefix ‘other:’ with a label token (alphanumeric characters, no spaces) of at least 2 characters to specify the service type

entry.label: 01 Geological Mapping
entry.description: Data collected and acquisition mostly in the field by profiling and stationary observation, sampling, and following laboratory analysis, etc., typically, regional field geological mapping

entry.label: 02 Survey
entry.description: Data collected with equipment records and following processing with planned profile, or areal/regional data acquisition activity, etc., typically, aeromagnetic survey.

entry.label: 03.0 Observation
entry.description: Data collected by stationary measurement, etc. like ground water monitoring.

entry.label: 03.1 Direct Observation
entry.description: (CGI) Feature observation is result of direct visual observation by a geologist (http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/direct_observation). Direct observation may include observation using a remote camera (e.g. downhole viewer, submarine camera).

entry.label: 03.2 Indirect Observation
entry.description: (CGI) Feature observation based on inference from proxy observation(http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/indirect_method )

entry.label: 03.3 Outcrop Observation
entry.description: (CGI) Data collected in field through direct observation of a single outcrop. Observer defines scope of 'single outcrop' - may be one point location, or averaged over an extended but connected area, e.g. a single polygon on a map (http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/outcrop_observation).

entry.label: 04 Remote Sensing
entry.description: Data collected with satellites, airplane platform on drone, etc., typically aero-photography and radar. Also, (CGI) Geologic unit or structure characterized based on remotely sensed data (http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/remotely_sensed_data )

entry.label: 05.0 Drilling or Borehole
entry.description: Collection or records of drills and boreholes.

entry.label: 05.1 Borehole Cuttings Observation
entry.description: (CGI) Data based on interpretation of borehole cuttings (http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/borehole_cuttings_observation)

entry.label: 05.2 Borehole Geophysical Log Measurements
entry.description: (CGI) Data based on interpretation of geophysical measurement obtained by borehole logging tools(http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/borehole_geophysical_log_measurements).

entry.label: 05.3 Drill Core Observation
entry.description: (CGI) Data collected through observation of a single drill core interval(http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/drill_core_observation).

entry.label: 06.0 Laboratory Instrumentation
entry.description: Data or resource from rock specimen and chemical element analyses in laboratories.

entry.label: 07.0 Data Integration Synthesis
entry.description: Data or resource are the result of synthesis from other data or resources, or as the integration of other data or resources.

entry.label: 07.1 Data From Single Published Description
entry.description: (CGI) Data are extracted from a published description of the feature (http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/data_from_single_published_description)

entry.label: 07.2 Synthesis From Multiple Sources
entry.description: (CGI) Feature observation is based on a synthesis of other observations by some compiler. The compiler may be the same individual that made the source observations (http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/synthesis_from_multiple_sources).

entry.label: 07.3 Synthesis Of Multiple Outcrop Observations
entry.description: (CGI) Data are the result of synthesis from multiple direct observations, possibly by more than one observer (http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/synthesis_of_multiple_outcrop_observations).

entry.label: 07.4 Synthesis Of Multiple Published Descriptions
entry.description: (CGI) Data are the result of synthesis from multiple published descriptions(http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/synthesis_of_multiple_published_descriptions).

entry.label: 08.0 Digital Conversion From Published Source
entry.description: (CGI) Feature observation is based on published information, converted to a digital representation for database application (http://resource.geosciml.org/classifier/cgi/featureobservationmethod/digital_conversion_from_published_source).

entry.label: 09.0 Digital Simulation
entry.description: Data generated by digital analyses and simulations with software rather than physical acquisitions.

entry.label: 10. Data and Map Compilation
entry.description: Geoscience data and map compilation from existing data, maps and other resources that are usually scattered and in larger scale and of higher spatial resolution. Or the collation of raw data and their transformation into a format that can be easily manipulated or combined with other data in preparation for further analysis(EiE Glossary, https://inee.org/eie-glossary/data-compilation).

entry.label: 11. Web Resource
entry.description: Data and resources obtained from the web.

entry.label: 12. Other
entry.description: Data and resources obtained from source other than the above. For other values not included in this codelist, use prefix ‘other:’ with a label token (alphanumeric characters, no spaces) of at least 2 characters to specify the acquisition method.
